Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant: Simulating Interactions Among Environment, Population Dynamics And Behavioral Response

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Amy Warren, under the guidance of Dr. Lisa Sattenspiel, will investigate the complex interactions between human populations and their environments to gain greater insight into the effects of resource stress and human adaptive behaviors on the structure of prehistoric human populations. A key adaptive strategy in response to resource stress throughout human history has been population movement at various scales. Prior research on population movements typically focused on large-scale abandonments in response to sudden, dramatic climatic shifts. This study instead focuses on changing climatic conditions, population dynamics, and population movements over a long span of time. The results of this research can be extrapolated to make generalized statements about human adaptations to climate and resource stress and, because these issues remain important considerations in the modern world, can potentially inform efforts to understand and mitigate subsistence stress among contemporary small-scale farming groups. In addition, sharing the methods, data, and results of this project with other researchers permits further investigation of questions of long-standing importance in archaeology. This project also incorporates activities that allow interested members of the public and even young students to perform their own experiments related to human-environment interactions.

Detailed environmental, demographic, and ethnographic data culled from years of archaeological and anthropological investigations in the American Southwest will be used in conjunction with agent-based computer simulation models to investigate these issues. The computer models developed in this project allow for realistic experimentation with various factors that contribute to prehistoric population dynamics. Fine-grained environmental data and research on the agricultural productivity of specific soil types under specific climatic conditions allows researchers to estimate annual agricultural productivity in two neighboring areas in the Four Corners region of the American Southwest, Long House Valley and Black Mesa during the study period (AD 800 to AD 1350). Incorporating this data into the models provides a realistic landscape on which the simulated populations can carry out essential activities. Using empirically derived estimates for fertility and mortality, one can simulate patterns of population growth and decline and collect data regarding possible structures of the prehistoric populations. This provides a means to generate prehistoric demographic data that cannot be produced using traditional bioarchaeological approaches. Several theoretical models, developed through ethnographic and archaeological research, provide basic information about the magnitude and duration of various population movement strategies in response to resource stress. Incorporating these theoretical models with the computer simulations allows for in-depth exploration of the nature of population movements between the two study areas and the effects of these movements on the structure of populations in the study areas. Implementation of these models permits not only a more nuanced understanding of some of the factors involved in changing population dynamics in the region but also allows for consideration of additional factors such as conflict and violence, disease, and sociopolitical complexity and their effects on prehistoric human groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Amy Warren has nearly completed research for her dissertation “Simulating prehistoric population dynamics and adaptive behavioral responses to the environment in Long House Valley and Black Mesa, Arizona” supported by the NSF Dissertation Improvement Grant. The key goal of this project was to contribute to the anthropological understanding of human adaptability to climate change in the study areas from AD 800-1350 by studying the effects of environmental change of population dynamics, reconsidering methods for the implementation of fertility and mortality in archaeological models. The project also explores the nature of migrations between the two areas.  These goals align with specific challenges recently raised by the archaeological community and represent the sort of data-intensive, multidisciplinary research that is necessary for progress toward addressing these challenges.

Two complementary research activities were required to address project goals and aims. First, it was necessary to accumulate the data that informs the model. To accomplish this, Amy Warren traveled to the National Archives to collect demographic data from the 1790 and 1823 Spanish and Mexican Colonial Censuses of New Mexico, collaborated with a team of ancestral Pueblo ethnologists and archaeologists to determine how to best model critical behaviors such as marriage and clan organization, and studied the available paleoenvironmental reconstructions for the regions.

The second part of the project required the extension of existing agent-based archaeological models, the Artificial Anasazi and Artificial Long House Valley (ALHV) models, to include structures that made use of the new or updated data. To this end, we developed four new models during the funding period. The ALHV-Baseline model included realistic marriage, kinship behaviors, and migration under a variety of circumstances. The ALHV-Demography Update included age-specific fertility rates and the ability to output each relevant demographic event that occurred during a simulation run. Analyses of these new models revealed that the timing and magnitude of the populations were better captured than in earlier models, even though the realistic cultural behaviors and fertility rates do not produce simulation runs that fit the archaeological data as well.

Following completion of the ALHV-Baseline and ALHV-Demography Update models, we began the process of incorporating more reasonable mortality rates and developing of a model for the neighboring Black Mesa region. In the ALHV-Age-Specific-Mortality (ALHV-AgedMort) model we include both empirically derived age-specific mortality rates as well as starvation rates determined through analyses of earlier model versions that included death by starvation. This model has as realistic as possible demographic parameters and structures but does not fit the archaeological record as well as previous versions of the model, reinforcing the importance of migration in population trajectories. Finally, we have just completed a stand-alone version of the model that represents the geography, environment, and populations on Black Mesa. While people can migrate into and out of their home region in both the ALHV-AgedMort and Black Mesa models and output the circumstances of the migration, we have yet to link the two. 

The results of this project to date provide insight into human adaptive strategies in response to subsistence stress, which remains a consideration in the modern world, especially in semi-arid or marginal climates for agriculture. Insights into the various successes or failures of prehistoric adaptive strategies as they relate to the perception of and reactions to environmental and climatic variability at different scales can inform policy decisions related to modern populations under similar subsistence pressures. The results of this project reveal that the interplay between demographic rates and environmental variability are much more complicated than previously understood and can help inform policy-makers attempting to mitigate the effects of climate change on modern small-scale horticultural populations.

During the funding period, Amy Warren has also been actively involved in K-12 STEM outreach efforts. From 2015-2016, she led a middle school coding club for girls, which was partially funded by this NSF Dissertation Improvement Grant and has presented her research to various audiences, including elementary, middle, and high school students as well as undergraduates. In March 2016, she presented to an audience of interested members of the public and various tribal representatives as part of the National Park Service Centennial History and Heritage Day at Casa Grande Ruins National Monument. Through these endeavors, she has learned to develop and disseminate research opportunities and activities for K-12 students and professional development materials for science educators. Recently, she has secured a position as Assistant Director of Outreach and Summer Programs at the University of Arkansas, where she will continue to bring STEM opportunities to underrepresented students throughout the state of Arkansas. The outreach experiences related to this project will continue to serve her as she completes her dissertation and moves forward with her professional goals.
